content.description: Two starts, both of which lead to a tenuous crux.  Fairly sustained climbing that involves some good movement on good rock.
content.location: Just right of Divine Tiger about 75 feet up the terrace.

content.description: Crux comes just at the first bolt (well protected) after you leave the secure "Demon Face Pockets" through the second clip. Sustained vertical face climbing after that, with a good rest before the finish.
content.protection: Bolts (7 or 8) and carabiners at the anchor.
content.location: Starts between Asymmetry 5.11- & Trihedrals 5.10+ (near the left side of Finland Terrace, where the trail splits).  Look for the interesting set of three pockets that form a "Spooky Demon Face" (two eyes and a mouth).  Bolts are a "cream" or "off-white" color.  First two bolts are close together to make for a well protected crux that comes after you leave the secure Demon Face Pockets.

content.description: Spicy! This is a solid lead. Fun line, good holds, and good crux moves.
content.location: Just to the right of Elsa.

content.description: The first 30 feet are engaging and fun. The second half gets a bit easier but is still fun.
content.protection: Bolts with Fixe hangers, Chain anchors.
content.location: Where the trail splits leading to the tier of Finland.  The route angles up and left a bit eventually climbing up one of three left facing dihedrals

content.description: This climb is pretty much a bolted boulder problem with some cool hard moves on slopers and sidepulls.  It has a lot of compression moves and open hand stuff.
content.location: First route right of Whiz Kids.  You will know you are on it as there is a ragged hole/pocket at the start and a chunk of dark chert sticking out above the bulge.

content.description: Short steep and sweet.
content.location: Third to last route on the Terrace. Not far from the knotted rope that you climb down to get to the Tufa City trail.

content.description: At the right side of a prominent dark hole in the rock. Boulder up to the hole, and clip the first bolt. Clean steep moves characterize this line.
content.location: This route begins about 10 feet right of Estevan’s Roof

content.description:
A nice, and relatively long for the area, route that involves some varied climbing. 

 Begin on the orange face next to a right-facing corner. Utilize the dihedral to gain a rest. Step right onto the face and begin climbing through a series of ledges and mantels. Finish on sharp grey fossil-laden stone.
content.location: Look for a clean orange face immediately right of a right-facing dihedral.

content.description: Probably the shortest route on the wall, only climbs about half way up the wall.
content.location: A short way up past the Terrace trail split.  Between Whiz Kids and Black Shadows.

content.description: Engaging climbing up a vertical face with pleasant holds.  Climbs better than it looks.
content.location: First route you encounter on the terrace.  It is tucked in a shallow amphitheater with Jiffy Pop.

climbs.name: Single Ladies
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers , John Hendrickson and Morgan - December 2011

content.description: A fun climb on a delicate face to an easy and juggy roof.
content.location: Right of Trihedral and left of "the pannus" feature

content.description: Climb drippy limestone to a roof. Set up on underclings and crank through the roof to an angular headwall.
content.location: Look for the big honeycomb pocket under a low roof. Right above a little saguaro growing on the tier.

content.description: This climb brings continuous moves until finally relenting at the anchors. Too bad it wasn't longer.
content.location: Located a few feet to the right of 'Stirring the Soup'

content.description: Clean face directly to the right of Disco Inferno. Cruxy through bolt three or so, then good holds to the top.
content.location: Face about 10 feet to the right of right facing corner right of Masterpiece Theater and Limestone Lumberjack. The corner is Disco Inferno.

content.description: Looks like it was equipped by Dave Iannuzzi.  Date unknown.Access route via the trail below using the knotted ascent/descent rope, or walk the Finland Terrace ledge.  The description picture will help you locate the route, as it starts underneath a small roof with two very obvious black streaks.Stick clipping the first two bolts is advised.  Crux is at the third bolt and involves some laybacking and a high right foot to work your hands up before hit a nice right hand side pull.  From here continue on small holds to a 2nd small roof.  Side pull again and move up and left to a good left crimp, cross over with your right to a nice pinch.  Stand up and continue to the 3rd small roof.  Route eases at the last bolt.
content.location: Upper end of the Terrace.  Just left of ExtendoCling.

climbs.name: Pannus Attack
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers, Cliff, Charlie King, December 2011

content.description: Easy and juggy face climbing to a roof/overhang that becomes a right facing dihedral. (Apparently the roof/corner feature resembles a pannus)
content.location: To the right of Single Ladies and left of Divine Tiger.  Exit to the right of "the pannus."

content.description: A hard cryptic start (a stickclip is nice) is followed by nice crimping up the featured wall. After a few bolts the jugs run out and a hard move is encountered to get below the roof. Pull the roof on jugs and get a nice no-hands rest on a large block. Continue up on easier ground to the top of the wall.
content.protection: On the terrace side of Finland. As you walk up the terrace about a 1/4 of the way up is this route. Between "Crystal Gazer" to the left and an "unnamed 11a" to the right.
content.location: 11 Bolts to Anchors, stickclip

content.description: Climb the beautiful orange face to the left of the popular Masterpiece Theater.
Nice route. Good warmup. Climb edges and underclings up to a grey shield of rock.
content.location: Finland Terrace right side. Second route after traversing past the fixed ropes. Just right of two armless saguaros.

content.description: Very hard moves past the first two bolts reach a jug at bolt 3. Strenuous moves lead up into the corner, culminating in the final classic roof.
content.location: Approximately 100 feet uphill from the Estevan’s Roof area is a prominent roof system with a clean right-facing corner defining its left end. Look for a line of bolts leading to this obvious dihedral/roof system.

content.description: Technical down low til you pull the bulge, then it becomes considerably easier. Fun moves, good line.
content.location: Two routes to the left of Masterpiece Theater. About six or seven routes up the terrace from where the trail splits.

content.description: Crux is down low with tricky moves in the first 25 feet. A good rest follows. Pull a few more interesting moves to the finish.
content.location: About 9 routes up the Terrace from where the trail splits.

content.description: Route bolted by David Stephens (aka Roadstead).  Date unknown.    You'll be pinching, sidepulling, underclinging, and crimping your way up this route.  Starts with a 10-move boulder problem (V6/V7?) culminating with a right hand in a good hueco hole.  From here it's 11- climbing to the top on sharp rock.
content.location: Starts on the tufas just left of Bloodline and turns the roof to the face above.

content.description: Short powerful crux that once surmounted leads to a steep face that can thwart your onsight or redpoint.  Unfortunately there is a section in between that has a good bit of popcorn.  You will want to have good calluses on your tips, as it isn't always pleasant feeling around to find the holds you will want to use to climb it.  Despite this bit of discomfort you will enjoy the moves and the route to the very end.
content.protection: 6 bolts to clip-ins. First one is high but the clip hold is a positive slot. Still might be tricky if you are shorter than 5.6.
content.location: Just to the right of Masterpiece Theater.  It starts on the right side of a section of what I think is flow stone that looks like a huge tree trunk.  You have to stand back a little to see it but you will notice a burl and a triangle shaped knot hole.

content.description: Steep pocket pulling at the start leads to  vertical face climbing.  Have to thank SA for cleaning most of it.
content.location: Just left of Elsa.

content.description: Short crack to a pretty dihedral with interesting moves.  A lot of popcorn like stuff about 25 feet up but it does not negatively affect the experience. BE CAREFUL ON THE CLEAN AS YOU WILL SWING ALL THE WAY ACROSS THE COVE AND SMACK THE WALL OR THE CACTUS.  Probably a good idea to stay clipped to your belayers side of the rope.
content.location: Just past the gully that separates Slate Nation from Finland in a small cove with a short saguaro on the left side. Also, a head high gray boulder at the back of the cove.  Starts in a crack then angles left to dihedral.

content.description: 5 bolts to biners
Fairly sustained route which makes it fun with no obvious crux.
content.location: Right end of Terrace just as the ledge widens up again.

content.description: Balancy and thin in a couple of places.  Some folks move into the crack down low which avoids the first crux.
content.location: Go past the first alcove (where Jiffy Pop is) on the Terrace.  As you pass a short gray undercut face you will find a crack that leads up the right side of the gray face.  The bolts right of this mark the route.

climbs.name: Grim Weeper
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers and Greg Kay, March 2011

content.description: The business comes early and late.  Doing the crux gets harder the longer you spend trying to figure it out.  It comes very close to the route that goes through the middle of the roof.
content.location: Route two or three to the right of Radical Self expression.  It climbs face below right edge of a fairly long 3 foot roof but busts right to avoid going over it.

content.description: Climbs over white bulge to small left facing corner at the anchor

climbs.name: Fight or Flight
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers, Brent Bingham and LA, February 2011

content.description: Good climbing on finger friendly rock leads to great moves to and past a good sized roof.
content.location: Just right of Radical Self Expression.

content.description: Steep gambler route.  Seldom climbed.
content.location: Upper end of the Terrace.  Just left of Dynamite Sex Sauce.

content.description: Solid, clean, nice looking line.
content.location: Near the center of the Terrace. Two routes to the right of Triple E.

content.description: The line cuts left at the first bolt and zig-zags a little. Easiest route on the wall. Use longer draws or skip bolts to avoid rope drag.
content.location: Near the middle of the Terrace. A couple routes to the right of Radical Self Expression.

content.description: I'll just let the name do the talking for this route.
content.location: Near the end of the Terrace. Immediately to the right of ExtendoCling

content.description: Not a straight up line. Route moves to the right slightly as you climb.
content.location: Just a couple routes up after the Terrace trail splits.  Just to the left of Whiz Kids.

content.description: Wierd, steep and juggy right facing corner system.
content.location: right facing corner system forming the right side of the "Masterpiece Theater" bulge

content.description: Start below a large pod and wander up and right past a few bolts to the arete. Climb up the arete and out a short roof to a fun but sometimes reachy jug haul finish.
content.protection: 10 Bolts to hooks. The anchor bolt on the rope traverse makes for a nice belay.
content.location: Crystal Gazer starts at the left anchor of the first rope traverse on Finland Terrace. The route climbs the prominent arete to left of the roof and stem box of Radical Self Expression

content.description: Different style than neighboring routes, pinches and open hand stuff to interesting rock up top.
Good warm-up route.  Starts straight up face on good holds with a few fun moves and then onto thinner holds on lower angle rock eventually moving right into a corner just before the anchors.
content.location: Left of Crystal Gazer and right of Ring of Fire. There is a semi-active beehive about 15 or 20 left on the terrace in a pocket. Don't swat at the bees!!!

content.description: One of the harder routes on the Terrace. This route ascends a thin red streak, hence the name.If you are already up on the terrace you can start the route from there.  Otherwise you can start this route from down on the trail. Starting from trail level requires a short but easy solo to the ledge.  First few clips of the route are on easy terrain.  The business is from bolts 3-5.  The crux is moving past the roof and requires some side-pulling, good footwork, and the use of a heinous right hand hold that can/will shred your middle fingertip. Once established on the bad right hand, set the left foot and make one more move to a slopy but decent left hand.  From here you can get your feet up and make a few more moves to clip the 5th bolt.  The route eases up from here.  Outside of working the route, my recommendation is to refrain from putting a draw on bolt 4, as it hangs right over the crux right hand hold.  I found it more work to clip that draw as opposed to making a few more moves to the better holds above.  If you double or triple your draw on bolt 5 it's a perfect setup.
content.protection: Bolted anchor below start. 8 bolts to rings.
content.location: Very last route on the Terrace.

content.description: Steep down low, pull the lip in the middle of the route and keep it together to the top.
content.location: Between So Keen and The Moose

content.description:
This route has a somewhat hard first move into a big flake before the first clip, good and attentive spotting (or a cheat-stick) is recommended.    It has really fun movement on steep rock up to a gray slab on top, then some thin balance moves right before the anchors.  

  I assume the name stands for the two distinct types of climbing. 

  Great line.
content.location: First route on the terrace in the left side of Finland, at the top of the approach trail.

climbs.name: The Annoying Orange
climbs.fa: Scott Ayers , John Hendrickson and JB - January 2012

content.description: Good climbing up orange face with easy on the fingers holds.  The crux is interesting and sustained.
content.location: Just right of Triple E.

content.description: East facing.  This wall has morning and early afternoon sun, shade the rest of the day.
